newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Volvo lifts N.America truck sale forecast.
newsitem.headline: Volvo lifts N.America truck sale forecast.

text.p: Swedish vehicle maker AB Volvo said on Wednesday that it was upgrading its forecast for North American truck sales.
The upgrade was applicable to both Volvo's sales and the total market, Volvo Truck's chief executive Karl-Erling Trogen said.
"We have revised our sales forecast for the total market for trucks in North America to 188,000 vehicles in 1997 from an earlier forecast of 165,000," Trogen told a news conference.
"We have also upwardly revised our forecast for our own sales but we don't want to comment on this in more details."
In 1996 Volvo's truck sales in North America fell by 38 percent to 16,900 vehicles.
"Vigorous measures are underway to restore the profitability of the U.S. business," Volvo said in its first quarter report released on Wednesday.
In the first three months of 1997 Volvo Trucks sales fell six percent o 10.94 billion crowns while operating income fell to 304 million crowns from 731 million.
Volvo said deliveries in Europe decreased 22 percent but were unchanged in North America. The number of trucks delivered in South America rose three percent.
